thread.title: SouthCoast in Action: SouthCoast Storm win four straight in Autumn Baseball League
thread.title_full: SouthCoast in Action: SouthCoast Storm win four straight in Autumn Baseball League

author: Tim Weisberg timweisberg@hotmail.com
title: SouthCoast in Action: SouthCoast Storm win four straight in Autumn Baseball League
text: Posted Oct. 18, 2015 at 8:00 PM By Tim Weisberg Posted Oct. 18, 2015 at 8:00 PM » Social News AUTUMN BASEBALL LEAGUE SouthCoast Storm 7, Taunton Independent 2 Curran Farnworth went 3-for-3 with three RBIs to power the Storm. Jordan Perez also had a hit. The Storm used six walks to help in the victory. On the mound, a trio of pitchers contributed to the win. Seamus Marshall worked the first two innings, allowing no runs on two hits and struck out a pair. Aiden Cardoza worked three innings, allowing a pair of runs on three hits and struck out three. Evan Mello worked the last inning, allowing no runs on one hit. He also struck out a batter. SouthCoast Storm 3, Taunton Independent 2 Curran Farnworth continued his torrid hitting by going 2-for-2 with a home run. Evan Mello had a double and an RBI. Jase Samagaio and Jared Assiaf also had hits. Mello had a great pitching performance, going 5.2 innings and allowing a pair of runs on five hits. He struck out six. Seamus Marshall came on in the last inning with the tying run on third to get the final out via strikeout to secure the win. SouthCoast Storm 15, Dartmouth 0 Curran Farnworth went 3-for-4 with an RBI, while Brayden Ventura also had a pair of hits and two RBIs. Seamus Marshall and Evan Mello also had two hits and an RBI each. Jase Samagaio and Jared Assiaf also had a hit and an RBI. Aiden Cardoza drove in a pair of runs while Cam Avila chipped in with an RBI. Marshall pitched the first two innings, allowing no runs and no hits. He struck out one. Ventura worked the last three innings, allowing no runs on a hit with six strikeouts. SouthCoast Storm 6, Dartmouth 1 Seamus Marshall and Brayden Ventura threw a combined two-hitter. Marshall worked the first three innings, allowing no runs on one hit while fanning two. Ventura worked the last three, allowing a run and a hit with five strikeouts. Offensively, Marshall and Ventura each had a hit and an RBI. Curran Farnworth and Zeq Alves also chipped in with hits while Cam Avila added an RBI. Other team members include Jase Samagaio, Evan Mello, Jared Assiaf, Aiden Cardoza, Ethan Kennefick, Hector Figueroa and Jordan Perez. SOUTHCOAST PANTHERS HOCKEY SouthCoast Panthers 3, Norwood 0 Nathan Coppellotti opened the scoring with an assist from Cullen Larrabee. Ben Saunders scored in the second, and Justin Gouveia closed out the scoring with an assist from Ben Austin. Matt Dore secured the shutout in goal, stopping a number of shots. Other team members include Leo Schiappa, Joey Pacheco, Matt Medeiros, Brandon Cardelli, Mason Dupree, Brady Becotte, Seamus Marshall and Dom Mauretti. GATEWAY YOUTH HOCKEY Gateway Pee Wee 5, Cape Cod Waves 1 The Gateway Pee Wee team played their toughest game of the season against the always strong Cape Cod Waves. The Waves held Gateway to just one goal in the first period, when Stephen Old scored off of an assist by Ben Martins. Gateway started to pull away with two more goals in the second period by RJ Vickery from Stephen Old and Nathan Ribeiro. The Waves scored a goal to narrow the lead to two, but Gateway sealed the deal with two final goals, from Old (from Martins) and Austin Fleming (from Luke Mello). Gateway Gladiator Bantams 6, WHK Hawks 0; Gladiators 7, SouthCoast Panthers 0 Goalies Jake Demoranville and Zachary Pateakos shared the shutouts. Jack Martins finished the weekend with five goals. James LHeureux scored a pair of goals. Robert Ramsay, Jameson Woodward, Peter Pimental, Chris Cogan and Ty Lovendale each scored goals. Quirino DoCanto and Ty Lovendale each had three assists, while Nick Snow had a pair of helpers. Zachary Lovendale, Brian Gallagher and Jackson St. Don assisted goals, as did Ramsay, Woodward, Cogan and Barris. Defenseman Noah DeMoranville was solid on the blue line. DARTMOUTH RESIDENT RECOGNIZED Benjamin Paine of Dartmouth was recently honored as one of this season’s Santander Soccer Scholars, recognizing his outstanding academic achievement. Paine was honored at Gillette Stadium when the New England Revolution hosted Orlando City SC, and he had the opportunity to meet and pose for a photo with Revs forward and Santander Soccer Scholars spokesman Charlie Davies. The Santander Soccer Scholars program recognizes the academic achievements and hard work of local students. Parents are invited to submit up to 100 words highlighting their child’s finest academic accomplishments from the 2014-2015 school year for the chance to win an opportunity for their child to participate in a VIP Match Day experience. A scholar is recognized at every Revs home game. MATTAPOISETT COMMUNITY TENNIS ASSOCIATION Tony Fera of Dartmouth recently the won the Mattapoisett Community Tennis Association’s Senior Tennis singles finals, besting Mattapoisett's Doug Simon. The Dartmouth doubles team of Al Humphries, Mike Hickey, Harold Kaufman and Tony Fera eked out a narrow win over Mattapoisett’s Syl Landry, Doug Simon, Wayne Miller and Henry Quinlan. By Tim Weisberg
